main-use-cases: Note-taking;Journalling;Task and project management (including CRMs);As a knowledge base (including technical, non-fiction and encyclopaedic content)
share-wikis: Yes, and I am the only editor/administrator of my wiki(s)
value-of-tw:
Used on scientific production systems which cannot connect to internet and seldom can be updated. 
Works without internet by customers. 
On Dropbox, works even in China, as Journal, Ticket and operation manual. 
I wish could be like advanced ticketing system.
tw-ability-level: I have customised TiddlyWiki through options and plugins;I am comfortable using WikiText widgets (e.g. <$transclude>, <$list>...);I have written custom HTML
save-method: Single-file wiki with custom saver (e.g. TiddlyPWA, Timimi, tw5-browser-nativesaver)
backup-method: Consumer online storage (e.g. Google Drive, Dropbox);DIY (any other solution)
diy-backup-info: task scheduler :  weekly powershell backup script. -> xcopy to archive\wiki.week.0x.html
project-strengths:
It will continue working after 10 years
It is open source
It can be easily updated.
project-weaknesses:
1) Timini plug-in was difficult to install in chrome in a closed env. (No internet). Grok TW seems good. 
2) I would like to have a kind of Demo Wiki. Showing a minimal Jira ticketing system. With : tool name & model & serial, part numbers, incident or ticket number, issue description, status: open, ongoing, cancelled,  closed. Your community size would increase. 
3) with Dropbox on my iPhone, I can see my wiki, but not work on it.
ok-to-publish: Yes, I am happy for my responses to be published
title: Community Survey 2025 Answer 00089
